docs.lead_paragraph: Wholesale changes must be made in the global response to diseases like Ebola.

headline.main: What It Will Take to Fight the Next Epidemic
headline.print_headline: What It Will Take to Fight the Next Epidemic

docs.abstract: Editorial highlights independent report criticizing World Health Organization's slow and feeble response to Ebola epidemic that claimed 11,000 lives; notes report's call for new leadership at agency and creation of independent center for combating infectious diseases; contends report makes clear that sweeping changes must be made before next epidemic emerges.
docs.snippet: Wholesale changes must be made in the global response to diseases like Ebola.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a sudden surge in news reports, the bugs have been in the United States for a long time, and the C.D.C. considers deaths from a disease they carry to be rare.

headline.main: No, Kissing Bugs Are Not a New Scourge

docs.snippet: Despite a sudden surge in news reports, the bugs have been in the United States for a long time, and the C.D.C. considers deaths from a disease they carry to be rare.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The study found that prices for 19 brand-name dermatology drugs increased about 400 percent in the last six years, but two of Valeant’s increases were the biggest.

headline.main: 2 Valeant Dermatology Drugs Lead Steep Price Increases, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Skin Drugs Lead Way in Price Rise, Study Says

docs.abstract: Survey published in journal JAMA Dermatology finds prices for 19 brand-name dermatology drugs have quintupled since 2009, with two Valeant Pharmaceuticals drugs increasing by 1,700 percent; observes that increases are unprecedented and are not due to drugs being new or exotic.
docs.snippet: The study found that prices for 19 brand-name dermatology drugs increased about 400 percent in the last six years, but two of Valeant’s increases were the biggest.

docs.lead_paragraph: After weeks of criticism from patients, doctors and other drugmakers for hiking a life-saving medicine's price more than fifty-fold, Turing Pharmaceuticals is reneging on its pledge to cut the $750-per-pill price.

headline.main: Turing Reneges on Drug Price Cut, Rival's Version Sells Well
headline.print_headline: Turing Reneges on Drug Price Cut, Rival's Version Sells Well

docs.snippet: After weeks of criticism from patients, doctors and other drugmakers for hiking a life-saving medicine's price more than fifty-fold, Turing Pharmaceuticals is reneging on its pledge to cut the $750-per-pill price.

headline.main: Amid Failure and Chaos, an Ebola Vaccine

docs.abstract: Under the pressure of spreading calamity, vaccines were readied to stem the Ebola epidemic even as it sputtered out. Now they’re available to rein in the next outbreak.
docs.snippet: Under the pressure of spreading calamity, vaccines were readied to stem the Ebola epidemic even as it sputtered out. Now they’re available to rein in the next outbreak.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the use of tests booming, the administration wants new regulatory powers, and even Republicans in Congress are looking at stricter standards.

headline.main: F.D.A. Targets Inaccurate Medical Tests, Citing Dangers and Costs
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Cites Dangers and Costs of Inaccurate Medical Tests

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration concludes that laboratory-developed tests not meeting FDA requirements for accuracy are responsible for putting tens of thousands of people on unneeded drugs, raising medical costs and prompting abortions or unnecessary surgeries; Pres Obama and members of Congress are currently working on ways to set stricter standards for certain tests used to diagnose and treat range of serious problems without FDA approval.
docs.snippet: With the use of tests booming, the administration wants new regulatory powers, and even Republicans in Congress are looking at stricter standards.

docs.lead_paragraph: Both groups said that the United Nations health agency’s outbreak and emergency response capacities should be strengthened, and protected from political meddling.

headline.main: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola
headline.print_headline: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola

docs.abstract: Health experts convened by World Health Organization release guidelines for responding to global health crises, after West African Ebola epidemic which killed over 11,000 people; panel asserts United Nations-affiliated WHO should be protected from political influence by independent overseer, and have its capacities streamlined and strengthened.
docs.snippet: Both groups said that the United Nations health agency’s outbreak and emergency response capacities should be strengthened, and protected from political meddling.
